articles.content:
8 low-effort ways to make Spooky Season feel cozy and festive 
         By Malaka Gharib 
        
           Saturday, October 4, 2025 • 5:00 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         Fall is a lot of people's favorite season, with its colorful leaves, its crisp air and its many opportunities for play and make believe.  But if you're feeling anxious about making the most of it, why not take a simpler, more mindful approach? 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       We've rounded up a few low-effort ways to make the lead-up to Halloween feel cozy and festive, whether that's becoming a pro at reheating frozen soup, creating a small ritual to mark the season (like switching from iced coffee to hot coffee), or giving yourself permission to go minimal with the fall decor this year. 🌡️Make simple adjustments to your lifestyle as the season changes .  "Prepare your nest" as the days shorten and the weather cools, says Kari Leibowitz, author of  How to Winter: Harness Your Mindset to Thrive on Cold, Dark, or Difficult Days . "Light candles. Switch from a cold breakfast to a warm breakfast. Switch from iced coffee to hot coffee." 🎃  When decorating for the season, consider how much effort you want to put into cleaning up   — like taking down all those cobwebs, bats and jack-o'-lantern garlands. "What goes up must go down," says interior designer Elaine Griffin, author of  Design Rules: The Insider's Guide to Becoming Your Own Decorator . So "think about your level of commitment to" putting away that decor. 🍁 On your next forest walk, take a moment to observe the natural cycle of life .  In many cultures, fall is a symbol of death and rebirth. Plants shed their leaves and prepare for winter dormancy, giving way to new life. Use your next nature walk as a way to reflect on the natural order of things. This is a particularly cathartic practice if you are grieving, says Gary Evans, director of the  Forest Bathing Institute , 🍎  Don't feel like you have to find the perfect Halloween costume.  It can be a lot of pressure to come up with a clever pop culture reference or decide on the movie character who you most admire. Why not try something fun, unexpected and irreverent instead? Be an inanimate object, like an apple or a baked potato, or heck, even "a bottle of Windex," says Los Angeles-based stylist  Sophie Strauss . 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       🎬 Find little tweaks to level up your home theater .  Fall is a time for  spooky movies  and comfort TV shows.  Devika Girish , editor of  Film Comment  Magazine, explains what you'll need to mimic the immersive experience of a movie theater at home. Watch the film on the biggest screen available to you (if you can, get a projector). Get some blankets. And fix yourself some snacks. Girish particularly loves munching on crisped chickpeas and popcorn and sipping a hot cup of cider while watching movies. 🍲 Make your leftovers go further and reheat frozen soup like a pro . Author and chef  Sohla El-Waylly  shares her advice: "Throw the frozen soup into a pot with a splash of water to get a little steam going at the bottom. Go for a low heat at first to get everything melted, then once it's melted, bring it up to a boil," she says. "Then give it a taste and see if you need to re-season it with salt. Oftentimes, it can fall a little flat, and you might need a squeeze of lemon to brighten everything up." 🥧 If making pastry dough for an autumnal pie feels too difficult, try making a tart.   "It's not as time-intensive or technical as a pie," says Lauren Ko, a baker and the author of  Pieometry . And many can be made without pastry dough. "Blend up some speculoos cookies with some melted butter and you have a shell. Or toast up coconut and pecans and add butter for another shell." 🚫 Opt out of a Halloween party or two — then let go of that feeling of FOMO . When you find yourself thinking the leaves are more colorful on the other side, remind yourself that the ones in front of you are pretty great too. "Maybe [you chose to stay in] because you had a long week and you need to recharge with some alone time. Or maybe you have an early start the next day. Whatever the reason might be, it's important to remember that as humans, we live by making a series of trade-offs," says  Aarti Gupta , clinical director at TherapyNest in Palo Alto, Calif. This story was edited by Marielle Segarra. The visual editor is Beck Harlan. We'd love to hear from you. Leave us a voicemail at 202-216-9823, or email us at LifeKit@npr.org. Listen to Life Kit on  Apple Podcasts  and  Spotify , and sign up for our  newsletter . Follow us on Instagram:  @nprlifekit .

articles.title: How 'neurodivergent' became a word for many types of minds
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores the evolution and cultural significance of the term 'neurodivergent,' which describes individuals whose cognitive and perceptual processing differs from societal norms. Originating in the late 1990s with Kassiane Asasumasu, the term was initially used in online autism communities as a more inclusive alternative to the narrower concept of 'neurodiversity,' which had become associated primarily with autism. Over time, the term gained widespread popularity during the 2010s and especially during the pandemic, when increased public discourse on mental health and accessibility led to greater awareness and acceptance. The article highlights that neurodivergence encompasses a broad range of conditions—including autism, ADHD, depression, bipolar disorder, Alzheimer’s, and even acquired conditions like long COVID or traumatic brain injury—and that intentional neurodivergence can result from practices like meditation or psychedelic use. While the term has become more mainstream, concerns exist about its narrowing use as a synonym for autism, reducing inclusivity. Newer terms like 'neurospicy' are emerging, particularly among people of color, reflecting cultural diversity in how neurodivergence is understood and expressed. The article also notes regional differences in cultural perceptions of neurodivergent behaviors, emphasizing that context matters. Overall, 'neurodivergent' is a dynamic, evolving concept that reflects both scientific understanding and social activism in recognizing and valuing diverse minds.
keyTakeAways: The term 'neurodivergent' is an umbrella term that describes individuals whose information-processing styles differ from societal norms, such as those with autism, ADHD, or depression.
Neurodivergence is not limited to medical diagnoses; it includes both innate differences and acquired conditions like traumatic brain injury or long COVID.
Intentional neurodivergence can occur through practices like meditation or psychedelic use, reflecting personal choices in cognitive or perceptual experience.

The term originated in the late 1990s with Kassiane Asasumasu, who used it on online forums for autistic people and later helped popularize it as a more inclusive alternative to the narrower term 'neurodiversity'.
The term gained widespread popularity during the pandemic due to increased focus on accessibility, mental health, and remote work accommodations.
Critics note that 'neurodivergent' has become increasingly associated with autism, reducing its inclusivity and excluding conditions like bipolar disorder or Alzheimer’s.
Newer terms like 'neurospicy' have emerged, especially among people of color, blending cultural identity with neurodivergence.
Cultural perceptions vary: behaviors like avoiding eye contact may be seen as neurodivergent in one context but normal in another, showing that neurodivergence is context-dependent.
The term is now used in multiple English-speaking countries, including the UK and Australia, though definitions may differ across regions.

articles.content:
How 'neurodivergent' became a word for many types of minds 
         By Ayana Archie 
        
           Wednesday, October 29, 2025 • 5:00 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         Our minds work in different ways. Despite all the research into our brains, a lot has yet to be discovered. But in recent years, many people  have championed a way to describe some of what we do know.  And that way is through the term "neurodivergent," which took off on Google trends amid widespread coronavirus lockdowns in June 2020.  Since the pandemic, "neurodivergent" has made waves online, in the media and in academic studies to help talk about neurological differences more inclusively. The term really got its start back in the late 1990s, and was added to the Merriam-Webster dictionary in 2002. In 2019, the Oxford English Dictionary added it as well.. So for the latest  "Word of the Week,"  we're talking about being "neurodivergent." What does neurodivergent mean? Neurodivergent is an umbrella term that describes people whose way of processing information is different from what society considers normal, according to Nick Walker, a psychology professor at the California Institute of Integral Studies. "Brains differ from each other in the way fingerprints do. 'Neurodivergence' establishes this idea that within the spectrum of neurodiversity, there are dominant norms and divergences from those dominant norms," he said. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       There is a widespread belief that "neurodivergent" is a medical term, limited to diagnoses such as autism or attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder. "It super is not," said neurodivergence activist Kassiane Asasumasu, who is credited with coming up with the word.  And there are different ways people become neurodivergent, said Walker. Some are born that way. Others develop neurodivergences because of things like traumatic head injuries or long COVID. And intentional neurodivergence can happen, for example, in people who meditate frequently or use psychedelics, Walker said.  Where the word comes from In the late '90s, Asasumasu was a high school student, active on online forums for people with autism. "Neurodiversity" had been coined a few years earlier  by autistic civil rights activists.  People often confuse neurodivergence and neurodiversity, but there is an important difference, Walker said. "The spectrum of human neurodiversity includes everybody ever, including people who are within the dominant norms," he said. "With neurodivergence, you diverge from something. You differ in some way from some socially constructed norm."  
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       But "neurodiversity" began being used as a synonym for autism, and everyone else was deemed neurotypical. Asasumasu said while "neurodiversity" was progressive, it wasn't enough.  "You've got typical, and what's the opposite of typical?" she said.  She began using neurodivergent first online, where she had the term in her AOL signature, and it became especially popular within online communities for autistic people. Then it spread to her school, where her peers were using it in face-to-face conversations.  Asasumasu, now a board member for the nonprofit Foundations for Divergent Minds, said she felt the need for a more general term. For one, some people have multiple neurodivergences. The term "neurodivergence" offers people who have them a way to express their differences without revealing their medical history or other private details, she said. It's also a way for people with neurodivergences to band together and leverage social and political power. "It's just good to have solidarity across disability," Asasumasu said.  How it became popular "Neurodivergent" gained widespread traction within the neurodivergent community in the 2010s, said Morénike Giwa Onaiwu, a researcher on neurodivergence and founder of the nonprofit Advocacy Without Borders. Walker remembers being taken aback when around 2010 or 2011, a student of his said they were neurodivergent while introducing themselves to the class. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "That was the moment where I was like, 'Oh, this is taking off somehow,'" he said. Then in 2020, the coronavirus pandemic helped thrust the term into news articles and casual conversation. Isolation and the onset of remote work led to public discussions about accessibility accommodations and mental health, Onaiwu said. "These were a lot of the accommodations that [neurodivergent people] had been begging for, and advocating for, that we were always told were not possible," she said. "But when the rest of the world needed it, it was something that was possible." However, Asasumasu said the word has started to become less inclusive as it becomes more popular.  Like "neurodiversity" in the '90s, people tend to now use "neurodivergent" as a synonym for autism, leaving out divergences like depression, Alzheimer's, bipolar disorder,  and more. "It is a very, very large tent," she said. "However big you think it is, it is bigger than that." In other ways, "neurodivergent" continues to expand. "Neurospicy" has emerged as a synonym, which Onaiwu said she first saw being used by people of color drawing inspiration from their various cultural cuisines. "Neurodivergent" is also becoming popular in other English-speaking countries, such as the United Kingdom and Australia, Walker said. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Onaiwu said her academic works have been translated into other languages, but notes that what is considered neurodivergent in some places may not be the same in others. For example, avoiding eye contact can be common in some places, and therefore might not be seen as a sign of neurodivergence as it could in the U.S. Some cultures may be more accepting and don't feel the need to label neurodivergences, while they may be heavily stigmatized in others. As people continue to learn about the experiences of those with neurodivergences, Onaiwu encourages them to stay grounded in shared humanity. "They matter just by virtue of being human," she said.

articles.title: Dining out with a big group? Learn the social etiquette of splitting the check
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article, written by Malaka Gharib and featuring insights from food editor and former restaurant owner Kiki Aranita, offers practical advice on the social etiquette of splitting restaurant bills in group settings. It covers five key scenarios: arriving late, not drinking, large party splits, birthday dinners, and shared appetizers. Aranita emphasizes that fairness, transparency, and consent are essential to avoid awkwardness and ensure equitable sharing. The article is part of a broader NPR LifeKit initiative on everyday life skills, promoting accessible, real-world advice for social interactions, and encourages reader engagement through voicemail and email channels.
keyTakeAways: When dining with a large group, it's important to establish fairness in splitting the check to avoid awkwardness.
If arriving late, request separate checks for drinks and appetizers to avoid complicated splitting later.
If not drinking, speak up to ensure the bill is split fairly, and consider contributing more to the tip to balance the cost.
For parties of six or more, splitting the check with two credit cards and using Venmo to divide costs among friends is a practical and efficient approach.
It is not automatic that friends will pay for a birthday dinner — the diner should be prepared to pay their own bill if they are hosting.
Before ordering shared items like appetizers, obtain consent from all diners to avoid unexpected personal costs.

articles.content:
Dining out with a big group? Learn the social etiquette of splitting the check 
         By Malaka Gharib 
        
           Tuesday, July 2, 2024 • 9:10 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         Let's say you're at a restaurant with a group of friends. You ordered appetizers, maybe got a bottle of wine for the table, went all in for dessert ... then the bill arrives.  No one is offering to cover the whole tab. So how do you handle the check? Do you split it evenly among everyone at the table? What if you only got a salad while your buddy got the surf and turf special? Splitting the bill is  a fine art . Whether you're eating family-style at a Korean barbecue joint or having a three-course meal at a fancy restaurant, there should be "a sense of equality in how the check is divvied up" when the meal ends, says  Kiki Aranita , a food editor at  New York Magazine  and the former co-chef and owner of Poi Dog, a Hawaiian restaurant in Philadelphia.  She goes over common scenarios you may encounter while dining out with a large group — and how to dial down the awkwardness by keeping things fair and square.  Scenario 1: I arrived to dinner late. Everyone at the table already ordered drinks and appetizers and are about to order their entrees. What should I do?  When you're ready to order, tell your server you want your food and drinks on a separate check, says Aranita. "It's easier to deal with than having to split a check in complicated percentages at the end of the night."  If you do choose separate checks, tell your server that at the start of the meal, not the end. That way they can make note of everyone's individual orders. Not every establishment offers this option, but it doesn't hurt to ask.  
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Scenario 2: Everyone ordered alcohol except me — and now they want to split the tab fair and square! Speak up, says Aranita. "Just be like, 'Hey guys — I didn't drink.' Usually, that's enough for everyone to reconfigure the bill to make it fairer. The problems only arise when you don't speak up."  If you are ordering round after round of $20 cocktail drinks, be conscious of the people in your party who didn't order as much as you. When the bill arrives, "maybe pick up a larger portion of the tip" to make up for your drinks, says Aranita.  Scenario 3: We're a party of six. Is it OK to ask the server to split the check six ways?  Many restaurants now have updated point-of-sale systems that make it easier for servers to split the check in myriad ways, says Aranita. But it doesn't always mean you should ask them to do so.  Aranita, who has also been a bartender and server, recommends a maximum of two to four credit cards. Servers "have enough to deal with" when working with a large party, especially on a busy night. And running several cards with different tip percentages isn't ideal.  "If you're a party of six, just put down two credit cards" and Venmo each other what you owe, she says. This approach also works out great for that person in your group who’s obsessed with racking up credit card points.  
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Scenario 4: It's my birthday. My friends should pay for my meal, right? In American culture, it's assumed that if your friends take you out to dinner for your birthday, they will cover your meal. But that's not always the case, says Aranita.  If you set up your own birthday dinner, don't expect to people to pay for you, she says. You picked the restaurant and invited your friends on your terms. So in this scenario, put down your card at the end of the meal. Your dining mates may pick up your tab, but if they don't, "that's perfectly fine. You're saying: 'I can celebrate me and also pay for me.' "  Scenario 5: It's my friends' first time at my favorite restaurant. I'm going to order an appetizer that I think everyone at the table will love. We're all splitting the cost of that, right? It can be easy to get swept away by the menu at a favorite restaurant, but don't assume your dining partners share the same enthusiasm for the twice-fried onion rings. "You have to get their consent at the beginning of the meal. Say, 'hey, is it cool if I order appetizers for the table?' " says Aranita. If you forgot to ask this question, assume that you will pay for the order.  This episode was produced by Sylvie Douglis. The digital story was edited by Meghan Keane. articles.title: Israel launches renewed strikes in Gaza less than 3 weeks into Trump's ceasefire deal
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Less than three weeks after President Donald Trump brokered a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas, Israel launched renewed airstrikes in Gaza, citing Hamas's alleged violation of the agreement by burying the remains of a deceased hostage. The Israeli military claims Hamas attempted to conceal the remains to evade international oversight, while Hamas denies the allegations, calling them baseless and accusing Israel of fabricating pretexts to justify further aggression. articles.content:
Israel launches renewed strikes in Gaza less than 3 weeks into Trump's ceasefire deal 
         By NPR's International Desk 
        
           Updated Tuesday, October 28, 2025 • 5:56 PM EDT 
        
        
      

         The Israeli military began carrying out renewed strikes in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, less than three weeks after President Trump brokered a ceasefire between Israel and the Palestinian militant group Hamas. Gaza's civil defense agency said there were initial reports of at least nine people killed and injured in Gaza City and the southern city of Khan Younis. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       The attacks came as Israel and Hamas traded accusations of violating the ceasefire deal that began on Oct. 10. The office of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced he had ordered immediate " forceful strikes " in Gaza following a meeting with his senior security ministers. They discussed what the response should be after accusing Hamas of attempting to stage the return of the partial remains of a hostage whose body the militant group was supposed to hand over under the terms of the ceasefire. The Israeli military released drone footage that it said showed Hamas operatives burying a bag with remains in the ground so that the International Committee of the Red Cross could find them. Netanyahu called the move a violation of the U.S.-negotiated ceasefire. Hamas said in a statement that Israel's allegations were "baseless and aimed at misleading public opinion." It said, "The occupation is seeking to fabricate false pretexts in preparation for taking new aggressive steps against our people, in blatant violation of the ceasefire agreement." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz said in a statement that Hamas would "pay a heavy price for attacking" Israeli troops in Gaza and failing to return deceased hostages.  On Oct. 19, the Israeli military carried out a series of airstrikes in Gaza after two of its soldiers were killed in Rafah. After those Israeli strikes, dozens of people, Trump said the ceasefire was still in place.  Hamas said it had "no connection" to the shooting of Israeli soldiers in Rafah. It said it would stick to the ceasefire and called on mediators to "take immediate action" to press Israel to stop its attacks in violation of the agreement.  U.S. Vice President Vance, who recently visited Israel, said he was confident the ceasefire would remain in effect despite the violence. "That doesn't mean that there aren't going to be little skirmishes here and there," Vance told reporters on Capitol Hill on Tuesday. "We know that Hamas or somebody else within Gaza attacked an [Israeli] soldier. We expect the Israelis are going to respond, but I think the president's peace is going to hold despite that."

However, the Abraham Accords with the UAE, Bahrain, and Saudi Arabia have survived the conflict, and renewed business ties are emerging. articles.content:
How Israel is winning the wars and losing the peace 
         By Greg Myre 
        
           Tuesday, October 28, 2025 • 3:47 PM EDT 
        
        
      

         TEL AVIV — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu recently stood next to President Trump in Israel's parliament in Jerusalem and summarized the last two years of war: "Israel achieved amazing victories over Hamas and the entire Iran terror axis — Sinwar, Deif, Haniyah, Nasrallah, Assad — they're all gone."  This list refers to countries (Iran, Syria and Lebanon), groups (Hamas and Hezbollah) and individuals (Yahya Sinwar, Mohammed Deif and Ismail Haniyah of Hamas, Hassan Nasrallah of Hezbollah and Bashar al-Assad of Syria) that have been Israel's main enemies for decades.   Yet at the same time, "While Netanyahu was winning wars, he was not able to win any of the peace, or any of the peaces," said  Paul Salem , who's based in Lebanon with the  Middle East  Institute . "He was not able to turn his military victories into sustainable political wins. He was digging Israel deeper into a hole." Israel has also come under withering international criticism. This is mostly over the Gaza war, which began with the Hamas-led attack on southern Israel on Oct. 7, 2023, which Israeli authorities say killed 1,144 people. In its ferocious response, Israel's military killed more than 68,000 Palestinians, mostly women and children, according to Gaza health officials. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Israel faces charges of genocide at the International Court of Justice, and Netanyahu has been charged with war crimes at the International Criminal Court. Israel and Netanyahu reject both these charges. For Israel, "From a purely military perspective, things look much better. From a foreign policy perspective, things could not have deteriorated much more than they have," said  Chuck Freilich , a former deputy national security advisor in Israel. "I think the war had a long-term impact," he added.  "It's going to take quite a while for Israel to regain its international standing of, let's say, 30 or 40 years ago."  Back in the 1990s, Israel and the Palestinians spent much of the decade trying to negotiate an end to their conflict, with the international community supporting those efforts. Friction in Israel-U.S. ties Today, the criticism of Israel comes from all directions. Outrage in the Arab world. Mass protests in European cities and on U.S. college campuses. Yet Freilich says his biggest worry is the U.S.-Israel relationship, which he has seen from both sides. He was born and raised in the U.S. He moved to Israel, where he became a security official. He still lives in Israel, but teaches for a semester each year in the U.S., currently at Georgetown University.  "For me, this is really the only existential threat that Israel faces, is a loss of American support," he said. "Israel needs the United States critically for just about every issue it faces." Israel used to have rock-solid bipartisan support in the U.S.  "Today there is an absolute collapse of support on the Democratic side, and we see the beginnings of a decrease in support on the Republican side," he said.  Trump remains a staunch supporter of Israel, but he has set red lines. He's pressuring Israel to stick to the ceasefire. He's explicitly told Israel not to annex the West Bank, where a half-million Jewish settlers live on land Palestinians claim for a future state. Salem says with these actions, Trump is showing a willingness to go against Israel in ways that previous U.S. presidents have not. "He doesn't always seem to follow what Israel or the Israeli lobby or the prime minister of Israel wants," said Salem.  Before the Gaza war erupted in 2023, some younger Arabs were not as passionate about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as earlier generations, which championed the Palestinian cause since the first major war in 1948.  The latest Gaza war has energized the younger generation, said Salem. "This is a war that was carried live on TikTok, and that did not happen in 1948," he said. "This has branded an entire generation." Relations cool, but agreements hold The recent fighting was also a stress test of the  Abraham Accords . Those are the 2020 agreements worked out in Trump's first term, which established relations between Israel and four Muslim countries. The war produced strains, but the agreements survived, notes  Erel Margalit , a prominent Israeli venture capitalist who began doing business in Gulf states after the accords were signed. "We have companies that are dealing with [United Arab Emirates] banks and Bahrain banks and Saudi banks and insurance companies and the government," he said.  Speaking more broadly about Israel-Arab business ties, which had largely stalled in the past couple  years, he said, "It's not being discussed too much out in the open. It's not being hidden, but it's quiet. I think a lot of it is coming back."  However, an improvement in Israel's international standing is likely to take time.   What the region needs, said Margalit, are Israeli and Arab political leaders who can move beyond the endless cycle of conflict. "There needs to be more political leadership, because the region could certainly use new initiatives as we're moving forward from this war," he said.  A lot may depend on what happens next in Gaza. If the ceasefire holds and rebuilding starts in Gaza, then Israel's isolation may begin to ease. But the ceasefire remains shaky. On Tuesday, Israel accused Hamas of firing on Israeli forces still in Gaza. Netanyahu ordered "forceful strikes" in response, and Palestinian officials reported air strikes in Gaza City late Tuesday night.

articles.title: EU Launches New AI Regulations to Ensure Transparency and Ethical Use in Critical Sectors
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In April 2024, the European Union launched a comprehensive set of regulations governing the development and deployment of artificial intelligence. The new framework targets high-risk AI systems—such as those used in healthcare, transportation, and public safety—requiring mandatory data labeling, impact assessments, and human oversight to ensure transparency, fairness, and ethical use. These regulations are designed to build public trust and prevent biased or harmful outcomes in AI decision-making. Compliance will demand significant changes in how organizations design, test, and deploy AI technologies, particularly in sectors where public safety and human welfare are at stake.
keyTakeAways: The new AI regulations introduced by the European Union in April 2024 aim to ensure transparency, accountability, and ethical use of artificial intelligence in public and private sectors.
The regulations focus on high-risk AI systems, particularly those used in critical areas such as healthcare, transportation, and public safety.
The EU's framework includes mandatory data labeling, impact assessments, and human oversight requirements to prevent bias and ensure fairness in AI decision-making.
Compliance with the new regulations will require significant investment and adaptation from both public and private organizations.

articles.title: Trump says he's confident of a deal ahead of Xi meeting
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, during a visit to Gyeongju, South Korea, former U.S. President Donald Trump expressed strong confidence in achieving a trade deal with Chinese President Xi Jinping ahead of their bilateral meeting at the Asia Pacific Economic Forum. The proposed agreement involves reducing U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods in exchange for China curbing exports of fentanyl precursor chemicals. The deal also includes China resuming purchases of U.S. soybeans and delaying export restrictions on rare earths, while the U.S. holds off on raising tariffs by 100%. Both nations are trading accusations of economic coercion, with the U.S. claiming China’s rare earth controls harm global supply chains and China asserting that U.S. tariffs and port fees are unsustainable. Trump also hinted at potential discussions on nuclear arms control with China, though North Korean missile tests during his visit suggest regional tensions persist. The article underscores the intersection of trade diplomacy, global supply chain stability, and geopolitical competition between the U.S. and China.

The proposed deal includes reducing U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods in exchange for China curbing exports of chemicals used to produce fentanyl.
The U.S. currently imposes a 20% tariff on Chinese imports, which Beijing has responded to with retaliatory tariffs on U.S. soybeans.
U.S. and Chinese economic officials met in Malaysia to lay the groundwork for a trade agreement involving China resuming purchases of U.S. soybeans and delaying export restrictions on rare earths.

The U.S. and China are trading accusations of economic coercion, with the U.S. accusing China of disrupting global supply chains through rare earth export controls, and China countering by asserting that U.S. tariff policies are destabilizing global trade.
Trump also raised the possibility of discussing nuclear arms control with Xi, suggesting China's potential inclusion in U.S.-Russia nuclear negotiations.
Trump emphasized that his primary focus during his visit to South Korea was the meeting with Xi Jinping, not nuclear talks with North Korea, which has been ruled out due to new developments.
South Korea's President Lee Jae Myung was briefed on U.S. efforts to resolve the ongoing U.S.-North Korea tensions, with Trump indicating he would work hard to de-escalate the situation.
North Korea conducted a successful cruise missile test during Trump's visit, adding to regional tensions.

articles.content:
Trump says he's confident of a deal ahead of Xi meeting 
         By Anthony Kuhn 
        
           Wednesday, October 29, 2025 • 6:02 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         GYEONGJU, SOUTH KOREA – President Trump on Wednesday confidently predicted striking a deal with China's leader in a bilateral meeting on the sidelines of the Asia Pacific Economic Forum, following a period of trade tensions that have threatened to escalate. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "I think we're going have a deal, I think it will be a good deal for both, and that's really a great result," Trump told a lunch meeting of APEC business executives in the southern city of Gyeongju.  "That's better than fighting and going through all sorts of problems," he added ahead of the Thursday meeting with President Xi Jinping. "No reason for it." Trump said that he could reduce tariffs on Chinese goods in exchange for a commitment from Beijing to curb exports of chemicals used to make fentanyl. "I expect to be lowering that because I believe that they're going to help us with the fentanyl situation," Trump told reporters en route to Gyeongju. "They're going to be doing what they can do." The U.S. currently imposes a 20% tariff on Chinese imports, in addition to other tariffs, because the U.S. government believes China has not done enough to restrict fentanyl precursor exports. In response, Beijing imposed retaliatory tariffs on U.S. soybeans. U.S. and Chinese economic officials met over the weekend in Malaysia to build the framework of a trade deal that would include China resuming purchases of U.S. soybeans. The deal would also include China delaying the imposition of export restrictions on rare earths, while the U.S. would hold off on raising tariffs by 100%. Both Beijing and Washington are trading accusations that the other side's economic coercion is wreaking havoc on the global economy. "This is China versus the world," Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said about China's rare earth export controls this month. "They have pointed a bazooka at the supply chains and the industrial base of the entire free world, and we're not going to have it," he said. "The U.S. has raised tariffs so high that it's brought globalization to the verge of breakdown," says Zhu Feng, dean of the School of International Studies at Nanjing University in China. He notes that besides tariffs, the U.S. has raised port fees this month on Chinese-owned or operated ships docking at U.S. ports. It has suggested controls on U.S. exports of software to China. And it has proposed barring Chinese air carriers headed to and from the U.S. from flying through Russian airspace. China's airlines have a cost advantage, because Russia allows Chinese carriers to transit their airspace, but not U.S. ones. "You can make China accept your rise in tariffs. But you can't keep overwhelmingly pounding on China so hard," he says. "China's retaliation is to show China and the world that the U.S. can't just keep us cornered," Zhu adds. Trump has also mentioned that he wants to discuss nuclear arms control with Xi, and possibly include China in U.S.-Russia nuclear arms control negotiations. Despite speculation that Trump might try to revive nuclear negotiations with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on this trip, that now seems off the table. Trump told South Korean President Lee Jae Myung at the start of bilateral talks that talks with Xi were his main goal. "We're looking forward to seeing him [Xi], and that was our focus, really, for this visit." Trump told Lee he was aware that the two Koreas remain technically in a state of war, and assured Lee that "we will see what we can do to get that straightened out. You know that I'll be working on this very hard." As Trump was visiting South Korea, Pyongyang said it had conducted successful cruise missile tests.

After a serious health scare and a local train crash that kills a classmate of her son’s, Rocky is emotionally and physically unbalanced. The story blends humor, warmth, and emotional depth, exploring family dynamics involving her supportive husband Nick, her aging father, and her anxious, queer daughter Willa. The plot is triggered by Rocky’s discovery of a rash and her investigation into a potentially negligent consulting firm that advised a railroad on cost-cutting maintenance. articles.content:
If you liked 'Sandwich,' you'll love 'Wreck,' its warm, witty sequel 
         By Heller McAlpin 
        
           Wednesday, October 29, 2025 • 7:00 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         Some characters are just too good to let go after a single book: Olive Kitteridge, Hercule Poirot, Tom Sawyer. And now, in  Wreck,  Catherine Newman has given Rocky, the sharp-witted, neurotically doting mother who narrates her delicious 2024 novel,  Sandwich ,  a repeat engagement. When we first met her in  Sandwich , Rocky was thrilled to have her husband, grown children, and aging parents all together under one roof during the family's annual vacation on Cape Cod. But squeezed between generations and moodily menopausal, she was feeling the weight of both past secrets and future change. Wreck  is even funnier, yet also more earnest in its explorations of life's fundamental impermanence. It picks up the story of Rocky and her brood two years later, back home in western Massachusetts.  Wreck  can stand on its own, but chances are, you'll want to read both books. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Wreck's  cover, like  Sandwich's,  features a soft-focus photograph of an alluring porch-fronted all-American house that telegraphs that this novel is not about a real estate teardown. In fact, the title refers to Rocky's state after being knocked off-kilter by a serious health scare and a local train crash that hits too close to home.  Newman's novel is animated more by wit, warmth, and worry than by plot. Its plot, such as it is, is set in motion when insomniacal Rocky, awake in the wee hours, googles the insidious rash that is spreading over her body. That's mistake number one. Mistake number two is reading a local news report about a high school classmate of her son's, who has been killed in a collision with an oncoming train at a railroad crossing. The rash leads to an increasingly alarming medical odyssey, while the train crash leads to disturbing theories about how this might have happened. One plausible explanation involves a consulting firm that advised the railroad to save money on maintenance. (It's more complicated than that, but I'll leave readers to untangle the situation.) 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       This isn't the first time Newman has made light of dire diseases:  We All Want Impossible Things,  her moving and improbably funny first novel about the death of a dear friend, was so convincing I thought it was a memoir. At her best, Newman evokes Nora Ephron. Rocky works from home writing what she's well aware are silly Home-ec type articles for various publications. She's a font of hilarious riffs about the absurdity of life — the ridiculous complexity of juice bar menus and the frustrations of modern medicine. She complains to her family about being fired from her own "etiquette column," but happily, we get to read her over-the-top angry email drafts to her editors before she wisely deletes them. Sometimes, Rocky's life feels like an updated version of cozy mid-century sitcoms about idealized American families. She's still the one cooking dinner every night and making coffee every morning for her unerringly supportive husband Nick, a physical therapist, her grieving 92-year-old father, who moved into their home temporarily a year ago after his wife's death, and her anxious, queer, migraine-afflicted daughter, Willa, who is back home from college, working in a local university lab while applying to Ph.D. programs in neuroscience. But unlike those sitcom moms, Rocky is a regular customer at her favorite marijuana dispensary. (A camping trip where she and her best friend get stoned and laugh uncontrollably falls flat.) 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       One of Newman's strengths as a writer is her ability to evoke widely shared predicaments with fresh images. When Rocky's father can't recall an old friend's name, she writes, "I know this exact feeling. I can be on my mental hands and knees, flailing around under the couch of my mind with a hockey stick, trying to sweep out a name I can't remember — and all I'll dredge up is a Ping-Pong ball, a catnip mouse, and a spool of thread. If I look away, though, sometimes it might creep out on its own little feet."  Newman can veer sentimental, but she mostly pulls off another mix of irreverent quips and heartfelt reverence in  Wreck.  At one point, frequently flippant Rocky describes herself as almost pathologically empathic," an undammable river of mother love."  During soothing woodland walks with her family and consoling cuddles with her daughter and cats, that river pretty much overflows its banks. Rocky gushes, "this moment, here, with my beautiful daughter in the beautiful world." Smitten parents will relate.

articles.title: Chicago Judge Orders Border Patrol Official to Daily Briefings Over Tear Gas Use in Immigration Crackdown
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A U.S. District Judge in Chicago, Sara Ellis, has taken an unprecedented step by ordering senior Border Patrol official Greg Bovino to attend daily briefings to report on the enforcement of immigration laws and the use of force. This follows weeks of tense encounters, including the deployment of tear gas during a children’s Halloween parade and protests in areas like Little Village and the Northwest Side. The judge demanded full use-of-force reports from agents involved in Operation Midway Blitz, which began in September and has resulted in over 1,800 arrests. Ellis emphasized that law enforcement must remain within constitutional bounds, banning certain riot control tactics and requiring body cameras. Legal representatives from news outlets and protesters allege violations of constitutional rights, and Bovino, who previously led operations in Los Angeles and El Centro, is now under direct judicial supervision.

The use of tear gas during peaceful protests, including a children’s Halloween parade, sparked public outrage and legal concern over constitutional rights.

Bovino, who previously led operations in Los Angeles and El Centro, California, is now under direct judicial supervision due to alleged violations of constitutional standards.
The judge mandated body cameras and training for agents after concerns over footage showing tear gas deployment without justification.

articles.title: U.S. Conducts Multiple Strikes in Pacific, Escalates Drug War Amid Diplomatic Tensions
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In a significant escalation of its anti-drug campaign, the U.S. military conducted multiple strikes in the eastern Pacific Ocean off Colombia, killing 14 people and leaving one survivor. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced the attacks as part of an 'armed conflict' with drug cartels, drawing direct comparisons to the post-9/11 war on terrorism. The actions have strained diplomatic ties with key regional allies like Colombia and Mexico, which criticized the strikes as violations of international law and sovereignty. The U.S. claims intelligence links to narcotrafficking vessels, though no evidence has been provided. The campaign includes accusations against Venezuela’s President Nicolás Maduro and the Tren de Aragua gang, fueling speculation that the operations are politically motivated. Mexico continues search efforts for the survivor and has called for diplomatic dialogue, while the Trump administration asserts its legal authority to target drug cartels, including potential land-based actions. The overall situation reflects a growing geopolitical rift between the U.S. and South American nations over the use of military force in counter-narcotics operations.

These strikes are the first in a single day, signaling a significant escalation in the pace of military operations against narcoterrorism.
The attacks occurred off the coast of Colombia, though Mexico claims the search area is 400 miles southwest of Acapulco, suggesting possible misalignment in reported locations.
Mexico has criticized the strikes, calling them a violation of international treaties and demanding diplomatic dialogue with U.S. officials.
The U.S. claims the boats were known to intelligence and on known narco-trafficking routes, but no evidence has been provided to substantiate these claims.
The campaign has strained relations with key allies, including Colombia and Mexico, especially after the U.S. imposed sanctions on Colombian President Gustavo Petro and his family.
The Trump administration has justified the strikes as part of an 'armed conflict' with drug cartels, drawing parallels to the post-9/11 war on terrorism.
The U.S. has accused Venezuela’s President Nicolás Maduro of narcoterrorism and has linked the operations to the Tren de Aragua gang, which is designated as a foreign terrorist organization.
Maduro has responded by claiming the U.S. is fabricating a war against him, and the U.S. has not provided verifiable evidence linking the boats to drug trafficking or the identities of the dead.
The Pentagon announced deployment of an aircraft carrier and warships, indicating a large-scale military buildup in the region.

articles.title: Judge Bars Trump Administration From Firing Federal Employees During Government Shutdown
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal judge in San Francisco has blocked the Trump administration from firing federal employees during the ongoing government shutdown, ruling that the layoffs are likely politically motivated and arbitrary. Over 4,100 layoff notices have been issued since October 10, targeting areas like education and health, with labor unions including AFGE, the National Treasury Employees Union, and others filing a lawsuit claiming abuse of power. The administration argues it has broad authority, citing Trump’s campaign pledge and his reality TV persona where he used 'you're fired' as a signature phrase. However, the judge has issued an indefinite preliminary injunction, preventing any further firings while the case proceeds. The shutdown, now the second-longest in U.S. history, has also led to a freeze on SNAP benefits and sparked political deadlock, with Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson refusing to negotiate until the government reopens. Democratic lawmakers are demanding restoration of expiring health care subsidies and reversal of Medicaid cuts from Trump’s prior legislation.
keyTakeAways: A federal judge in San Francisco, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston, has indefinitely blocked the Trump administration from firing federal employees during the government shutdown, citing that the layoffs are likely arbitrary and politically motivated.

The layoffs, which include cuts in education, health, and other federal programs, were challenged by labor unions including the American Federation of Government Employees (AFGE), National Treasury Employees Union, American Federation of Teachers, and International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers.

The administration claimed it had broad authority to reduce the workforce as promised during the 2024 presidential campaign, referencing President Trump’s popularity from his reality TV show 'The Apprentice' where he famously used the phrase 'you're fired'.
The lawsuit has expanded to include all Cabinet departments and over twenty independent federal agencies, indicating broad scope of the legal challenge.
Approximately 4,100 layoff notices were issued since October 10, with some sent to email addresses that furloughed employees cannot access, raising concerns about transparency and fairness.
The government has not tapped into about $5 billion in contingency funds to maintain benefits under the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) through November.
Democratic lawmakers are demanding that any deal to reopen the government include restoration of expiring health care subsidies and reversal of Medicaid cuts from Trump's tax and spending bill.
Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson has refused to negotiate with Democrats until they agree to reopen the government, prolonging the shutdown.
This shutdown is now the second-longest in U.S. history, following the 35-day shutdown in 2019 during Trump’s first term over demands for a border wall fund.

articles.title: Corporate Layoffs and Job Market Turmoil Amid AI Investment and Economic Uncertainty
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. job market is experiencing a wave of corporate layoffs, driven by economic uncertainty, rising operational costs, and aggressive investments in artificial intelligence. Major companies including Amazon, UPS, Target, Nestlé, Lufthansa, Novo Nordisk, and Microsoft have announced significant workforce reductions. These cuts are linked to strategic shifts toward AI development, cost-cutting, and corporate streamlining. Federal employees have also faced job instability due to the ongoing government shutdown, adding to broader worker anxiety. Analysts suggest that the job market is in a 'no-hire, no-fire' standstill, with companies prioritizing capital investment over employment, resulting in a climate of uncertainty for workers and businesses alike.
keyTakeAways: The U.S. job market is facing a significant downturn, with major corporations cutting thousands of jobs amid economic uncertainty and rising operational costs.
AI investment is a key driver behind corporate restructuring — companies are redirecting capital from workforce to technology, leading to indirect job losses.
Government shutdowns and federal policy shifts, such as new tariffs under the Trump administration, are exacerbating worker anxieties and contributing to job instability.

Multiple large firms — including Amazon, UPS, Target, Nestlé, Lufthansa, Novo Nordisk, ConocoPhillips, Microsoft, and Procter & Gamble — have announced significant layoffs, indicating a widespread trend in corporate downsizing.
Layoffs are not uniformly distributed; they are concentrated in corporate and administrative roles, with some companies emphasizing cost-cutting to maintain competitiveness.

articles.title: Bill Gates Proposes Strategic Pivot in Climate Policy: Focus on Poverty and Disease Over Emission Reduction
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Bill Gates, through a memo released ahead of the upcoming U.N. climate conference in Brazil, argues that the global climate effort should shift focus from limiting temperature rise to addressing poverty and preventing disease—especially in the world’s poorest nations. He asserts that eradicating malaria is more valuable than a 0.1-degree warming, emphasizing that human suffering is a more pressing priority. Gates calls for a strategic pivot in climate policy, urging world leaders to assess whether current climate funding is being spent efficiently. He highlights Breakthrough Energy and AI-driven innovation as tools to achieve clean energy transitions, while criticizing declining foreign aid for health programs like Gavi, which he sees as essential for climate resilience. Despite widespread scientific consensus that every fraction of a degree of warming matters, Gates' pragmatic, innovation-centered view has sparked debate, with experts noting the risks of underestimating climate impacts on ecosystems and natural systems.
keyTakeAways: Bill Gates believes climate change is serious but not an apocalyptic end to civilization; instead, he emphasizes scientific innovation and human well-being as primary solutions.
Gates advocates for a strategic pivot in climate policy from limiting warming to combating poverty and preventing disease, especially in the world’s poorest regions.
He argues that eradicating malaria is more valuable than a 0.1-degree increase in warming, asserting that preventing suffering in vulnerable populations is a higher priority.

Gates' memo, released ahead of the upcoming U.N. climate conference in Brazil, calls for a reevaluation of how climate funds are allocated—questioning whether they are spent on the most effective interventions.
He criticizes shrinking foreign aid budgets, particularly for health programs like Gavi, which could reduce life-saving vaccine access in vulnerable countries during climate-related crises.
Gates believes innovation in clean energy, especially through Breakthrough Energy, can make clean technologies cost-competitive with fossil fuels, and that AI is accelerating this progress.
He stresses that aid spending must be extremely efficient—only supporting initiatives that deliver significant, measurable benefits in health and development.
While some climate scientists agree that human well-being should be a priority, others argue that this view underestimates the risks to ecosystems and irreversible climate tipping points.
The Paris Agreement’s 1.5°C warming goal is now nearly unattainable due to projected emissions, reinforcing the urgency of both climate action and development efforts.

articles.title: Students and Retiree Group Ask Judge to Intervene in 2020 Census Lawsuit
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Two University of Central Florida students and the Alliance for Retired Americans are seeking to intervene in a federal lawsuit filed by young Republican groups challenging the 2020 census results. They argue that the Trump administration may not vigorously defend the census, raising fears that a settlement could lead to undercounting residents in group quarters such as college dorms and nursing homes. The lawsuit targets two key methods used in the census — differential privacy and imputation — which experts say may have reduced the count. The data collected is essential for determining congressional representation and federal spending, making the integrity of the census vital to democratic governance. The legal challenge is part of a broader political effort by Republicans to influence redistricting ahead of the 2024 midterms, especially given Trump’s past attempts to exclude undocumented immigrants from the census, which contradicts the 14th Amendment's requirement to count all residents.
keyTakeAways: The 2020 census results are being challenged in federal court by young Republican groups, raising concerns that the data may be altered through settlement agreements, potentially undercounting people in group quarters like college dorms and nursing homes.
The Trump administration previously attempted to exclude undocumented immigrants from the census, contradicting the 14th Amendment, which requires counting all residents in the U.S.
Statistical methods like differential privacy and imputation — used to protect privacy and fill missing data — are being contested for potentially skewing population counts.
The census data directly determines congressional seat allocation and federal spending distribution, making its integrity critical to democratic governance and public funding.

The lawsuit involves a coalition of two University of Central Florida students and the Alliance for Retired Americans, who fear the Trump administration may not defend the census results vigorously, leading to a potentially biased outcome.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. federal executive branch under former President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration is central to the article as it initiated policies and actions — such as pressuring the Census Bureau to exclude undocumented immigrants and attempting to end the 2020 census — that are now being challenged in court.

namedEntities.name: 2020 census
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The decennial national headcount used to determine state representation and federal spending
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 2020 census results are at the heart of a legal challenge, with concerns that the data may be altered, impacting how congressional seats and federal funds are allocated.

namedEntities.name: Alliance for Retired Americans
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nonprofit advocacy group representing the interests of older Americans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The group is urging intervention in the lawsuit, concerned that undercounting in nursing homes could disadvantage retirees and reduce federal funding for elderly services.

namedEntities.name: University of Central Florida
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A public university in Orlando, Florida
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Two students from this university are formally requesting to intervene in the lawsuit, indicating student involvement in political and policy debates over census integrity.

namedEntities.name: University of South Florida College Republicans
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A student group at the University of South Florida affiliated with the Republican Party
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This group filed a legal challenge with young Republican groups, arguing that certain census methods could lead to undercounting in group quarters.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A local Republican youth advocacy group in Pinellas County, Florida
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This group co-led the lawsuit challenging census data methods, aiming to influence redistricting in Florida ahead of the 2024 midterms.

namedEntities.name: Jeffrey Wice
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A professor at New York Law School
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He expressed concerns that the Commerce Department might not defend the census data, highlighting a potential lack of institutional commitment to protect the original count.

namedEntities.name: 14th Amendment
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A constitutional provision stating that all persons in each state must be counted
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The amendment is cited as the legal foundation for counting all residents, regardless of immigration status, and is central to the dispute over census methodology and eligibility.

namedEntities.name: Differential privacy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A statistical technique used to protect individual identity in census data by adding intentional errors
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This method is being challenged as a potential tool for obscuring true population counts, especially in group quarters like dorms and nursing homes.

namedEntities.name: Imputation
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A data-filling technique used when census takers cannot reach individuals at an address
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This method is under legal scrutiny as a possible factor in undercounting residents in group quarters, such as college dorms and nursing homes.

namedEntities.name: Group quarters
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Residential spaces including college dorms, nursing homes, and shared housing where people live under one roof
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article emphasizes that people in group quarters are at risk of being undercounted, which could lead to unfair redistricting and reduced federal funding.

namedEntities.name: Federal spending
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Annual allocations of $2.8 trillion in federal funds
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The census determines how federal funds are distributed, so any undercounting could lead to reduced resources for communities, especially in vulnerable sectors.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa Pummeled Jamaica and Cuba with Catastrophic Winds and Floods
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Hurricane Melissa, a Category 5 storm with 185 mph winds and record-low central pressure, made landfall in southwestern Jamaica, becoming one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes on record. The storm caused catastrophic damage, including widespread flooding, power outages, structural collapse, and landslides, with at least three families trapped in Black River. Officials reported that no infrastructure in the region can withstand such a storm, and recovery efforts are expected to be slow. Over 15,000 people were sheltered, and more than 77% of Jamaica’s population lost power. A hospital in St. Elizabeth was underwater, and one lost power, forcing evacuation of 75 patients. The U.S. Hurricane Hunters flew multiple missions to gather data. The storm also affected Cuba, with officials warning of a storm surge and evacuating over 200,000 people. In both nations, communities faced extreme weather, displacement, and anxiety, prompting humanitarian aid from the U.N. and NGOs. The article underscores the immense human, infrastructural, and environmental toll of such extreme weather events.
keyTakeAways: Hurricane Melissa was a Category 5 storm, one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes on record, with sustained winds of 185 mph (295 kph) and a central pressure of 892 millibars.
The storm caused widespread destruction in southwestern Jamaica, including flooded homes, fallen buildings, power outages, and landslides.
Over 15,000 people were sheltered, and approximately 540,000 customers (77%) lost power; four major hospitals were damaged, with one losing power and evacuating 75 patients.
Seven fatalities were reported across the Caribbean, including three in Jamaica, three in Haiti, and one in the Dominican Republic.
The U.S. Air Force Reserve 'Hurricane Hunters' collected critical weather data during multiple flights through Melissa to support the National Hurricane Center.
A pregnant woman in labor was assisted via radio call, with an obstetrician providing guidance on emergency delivery due to hospital access issues.
Hurricane Melissa was expected to make landfall in eastern Cuba, bringing up to 20 inches of rain and a storm surge of up to 13 feet.
Cuban officials evacuated over 200,000 people from vulnerable areas in Holguín and Banes, and residents sought shelter in community centers like the home of 83-year-old Eduviges Figueroa.
Jamaican officials emphasized that recovery and damage assessment would be slow due to the lack of infrastructure capable of withstanding a Category 5 storm.
International aid, including food, medicine, and emergency supplies, was pre-positioned for distribution after the storm.

articles.title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’

The WMO highlights that disasters have killed over 2 million people in the past 50 years, with 90% of deaths in developing countries. Despite progress—such as increased adoption of early-warning systems in 62 countries—the situation remains dire, especially in conflict-affected or fragile regions. The article references real-world examples, including the 2025 flooding in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US. A key case study is Switzerland’s successful evacuation of Blatten due to a predicted glacier collapse in May 2025, illustrating the life-saving potential of timely monitoring. The WMO stresses that early warnings must translate into early action, emphasizing that the goal is not just to alert but to empower communities globally to respond and survive climate-driven disasters.

The WMO reports that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of such deaths occurring in developing countries over the past 50 years.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), 50% of the assessed 62 countries still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most severe in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being observed in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning early-warning websites and standardized alert systems.
The WMO emphasizes that early warnings enable early action, stating that their goal is not just to warn but to empower communities and governments to respond effectively.
Real-world examples, such as the 2025 glacier collapse in Switzerland and the evacuation of Blatten, illustrate the life-saving potential of monitoring and early warning systems.
Climate change is causing weather patterns to become more extreme, leading to a 'spiral' of increasing impacts on human life, infrastructure, and economies globally.

articles.content:
Published: 2025-10-20T12:35:15+00:00

Title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’

Nearly half of all countries lack early-warning systems for extreme weather events, leaving millions – especially those in developing nations – vulnerable.

As it released a new report on Monday, the UN’s World Meteorological Organization (WMO) called for gaps in global monitoring and forecasting networks to be plugged. Timely alerts are crucial to saving lives as extreme weather events multiply due to climate change, it warned.

“Many millions of people lack protection against dangerous weather, which is inflicting an increasing toll on economic assets and vital infrastructure,” said a statement by the WMO, noting that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems.

The organisation said weather, water and climate-related hazards have killed more than 2 million people in the past 50 years. It added that 90 percent of those deaths occurred in developing countries.

“Impacts are spiralling as weather becomes more extreme,” it said.

The WMO acknowledged that there has been “huge progress” in climate monitoring over the last decade. The number of countries using some form of multi-hazard early warning systems has jumped from 52 to at least 108.

However, it continued, an assessment of 62 countries showed half of them possess only basic capacity and 16 percent have less than basic capacity.

“The situation is worst in fragile, conflict and violence-affected contexts,” the organisation said.

Nevertheless, the WMO is seeing progress in Africa, with more countries having functioning websites and issuing standardised alerts.

“Early warning means early action. Our goal is to not only warn the world; it is to empower it,” WMO Secretary-General Celeste Saulo said in a speech as the UN institution opened its annual conference in Geneva on Monday.

The world has been rocked by numerous weather-related disasters in 2025. Huge  flooding has rocked countries including Pakistan ,  Nigeria  and  South Korea . Wildfires have devastated large areas in  southern Europe , as well as  the US .

The head of Switzerland’s Federal Department of Home Affairs, Elisabeth Baume-Schneider, told delegates at the conference that no country or region was spared from the effects of climate change and extreme weather.

She pointed to the example of how the regular monitoring of a mountain glacier allowed scientists to warn about its imminent collapse in May 2025, allowing for the evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten.

“Permafrost melt will inevitably lead to more glacier collapses and rockfalls,” making early warning systems vital, she said.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa takes aim at Caribbean, islands on alert
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical Storm Melissa, the first named storm of the Caribbean this year and the 13th of the Atlantic hurricane season, is moving slowly toward the Caribbean, threatening landslides and life-threatening flooding across Jamaica, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, and other islands. With up to 12 inches of rain expected in Jamaica’s eastern region and heavy rainfall forecast across southern Haiti, southern Hispaniola, Aruba, and Puerto Rico, officials are urging residents to evacuate flood-prone areas. The storm has sustained winds of 50mph and is projected to strengthen into a hurricane by Friday and a major hurricane by the late weekend. This event is part of a broader above-normal hurricane season forecasted by NOAA, with implications for regional safety, infrastructure, and emergency response systems.
keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Melissa is threatening the Caribbean islands with dangerous landslides and life-threatening flooding.
Jamaica’s eastern region could see up to 12 inches (300mm) of rain, a significant amount that officials emphasize as a primary concern.
Similar heavy rainfall is expected in southern Haiti and the southern Dominican Republic, with potential for more rain depending on the storm's path.
Heavy rain is also forecast for western Jamaica, southern Hispaniola, Aruba, and Puerto Rico.

Melissa has maximum sustained winds of 50mph (85km/h) and is moving slowly at 2mph (4km/h), centered about 335 miles south-southwest of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and 295 miles south-southeast of Kingston, Jamaica.
The storm could strengthen into a hurricane by Friday and a major hurricane by the late weekend.
Melissa is the 13th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season and the first named storm to form in the Caribbean this year.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) predicted an above-normal Atlantic hurricane season with 13 to 18 named storms, including five to nine hurricanes and two to five major hurricanes (with winds of 111mph or greater).

Title: Tropical Storm Melissa takes aim at Caribbean, islands on alert

Tropical Storm Melissa is threatening the Caribbean Sea islands with dangerous landslides and life-threatening flooding, as officials urge residents of flood-prone areas to seek higher ground and shelter.

Jamaica’s eastern region could see up to 12 inches (300mm) of rain. “Now that is significant rainfall, and that is the main thing that we should be mindful of at this time,” Evan Thompson, director of Jamaica’s Meteorological Service, said.

Similar rainfall amounts were expected for southern Haiti and the southern Dominican Republic through Saturday, with even more rain possible locally, depending on Melissa’s path later in the week.

Heavy rain was also forecast for western Jamaica, southern Hispaniola, Aruba and Puerto Rico.

Melissa had maximum sustained winds of 50mph (85km/h) and was moving west at 2mph (4km/h) late on Wednesday night, according to the US National Hurricane Center in Miami.

The slow-moving storm was centred about 335 miles (535km) south-southwest of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and some 295 miles (475km) south-southeast of Kingston, Jamaica.

The NHC said the storm could strengthen gradually in the coming days and grow into a  hurricane  by Friday and a major hurricane by the late weekend.

Heavy rains in the Dominican Republic have already disrupted traffic and led to the cancellation of sports events.

Melissa is the 13th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, and the first named storm to form in the Caribbean this year.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted an above-normal Atlantic hurricane season – which runs from June 1 to November 30 – with 13 to 18 named storms.

Of those, five to nine were forecast to become hurricanes, including two to five major hurricanes, which pack winds of 111mph or greater.

articles.title: Five dead, two missing as Tropical Storm Fengshen soaks Philippines
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical Storm Fengshen caused extensive damage across the Philippines in October 2025, resulting in at least five deaths and two missing persons. The storm triggered deadly flooding and landslides, with a family in Quezon province killed when a tree fell on their bamboo house, and two people reported missing after a vehicle fell off a highway in Bukidnon, Mindanao. Over 47,000 people evacuated to shelters, and multiple dams released water to manage flood risks. The event occurred amid a recovery period following a series of earthquakes that killed at least 87 people, prompting President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. to call for stronger disaster preparedness due to the country's high vulnerability to natural disasters. Climate scientists warn that extreme weather events are intensifying due to global warming.
keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Fengshen caused significant loss of life and infrastructure damage in the Philippines, especially in Luzon and Mindanao.
At least five people were killed and two reported missing due to flooding, landslides, and structural collapses.
A family in Quezon province was killed when a palm tree fell on their bamboo house, with one teenage boy surviving.
More than 47,000 people evacuated to temporary shelters as the storm intensified.
Fengshen triggered landslides and flooding, including in Calbayog City and Bukidnon, disrupting transportation and safety.
The Philippines is vulnerable to frequent storms and typhoons, with scientists linking increasing storm intensity to climate change.

Title: Five dead, two missing as Tropical Storm Fengshen soaks Philippines

At least five people have been killed and two reported missing as  Tropical Storm Fengshen  sweeps through the Philippines, triggering heavy flooding on the main island of Luzon and a vast landslide on the southern island of Mindanao.

In Quezon province in the north of the country, five members of one family, including two children, were crushed to death when a tree fell on their bamboo house early on Sunday, according to Philippine disaster agency officials in the town of Pitogo, where the incident took place.

Images posted on social media by officials showed the house destroyed under the weight of a large palm tree, as a rescue team worked to remove the bodies of the family.

According to a statement shared on social media, a teenage boy was the lone survivor of the accident in Pitogo, about 153km (95 miles) southeast of the capital Manila.

More than a dozen flights were ordered cancelled by aviation authorities as Fengshen hovered over Luzon, situated just south of Manila, as of Sunday afternoon. The storm was reported to be moving west towards the South China Sea.

The AFP news agency quoted officials in southeastern Luzon as saying at least 47,000 people had left their homes for the safety of government-designated temporary shelters since Saturday. At least five dams on Luzon island opened their gates to release water on Sunday, according to the national weather agency, Pagasa.

In the central Philippines, heavy flooding was reported by officials on the islands of Samar and Panay, forcing residents to evacuate.

One person was injured in the town of Estancia on Panay Island after he was pinned down following the collapse of his wooden house, the ABS-CBN news website reported.

Rumagasa ang baha sa ilang barangay sa Calbayog City, Samar dahil sa hagupit ng bagyong  #RamilPH  sa lugar ngayong Linggo, October 19. | via Ranulfo Docdocan

(Courtesy: Reymark Espinosa)  pic.twitter.com/dJAV5eOdZo

— ABS-CBN News (@ABSCBNNews)  October 19, 2025

Translation: Raging floodwater inundated several areas of Calbayog City in Samar due to Tropical Storm Ramil [Fengshen] as of Sunday, October 19.

In the province of Bukidnon on the southern island of Mindanao, two people were reported missing after their motorised three-wheel vehicle fell off a highway following a large landslide triggered by the heavy rains.

Public works officials said the highway, which connects Bukidnon to the neighbouring Davao region, is now blocked to traffic.

On average, the Philippines is hit by about 20 storms and typhoons each year, and scientists warn that extreme weather events are becoming more powerful as the planet warms due to human-driven climate change.

Fengshen also comes as the Philippines started to recover from  a series of major earthquakes  that killed at least 87 people over the past three weeks.

In a Facebook post published on Sunday, Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr said the country needs to “strengthen its disaster preparedness and response” as it is “very prone to having disasters and calamities”.

articles.title: What caused Amazon’s AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: An AWS outage beginning at 07:11 GMT caused a cascading failure across 113 services, disrupting major apps including banking platforms (Venmo), communication tools (WhatsApp, Zoom), gaming services (Roblox, Fortnite), media companies (The New York Times, Wall Street Journal), and consumer devices (Alexa, Ring). The root cause was a flawed software update to DynamoDB’s API, which disrupted the Domain Name System (DNS), preventing apps from connecting to critical databases. The issue originated in AWS’s Virginia data center and was resolved by 10:11 GMT, though some users experienced processing delays. Experts emphasize that such outages are typically due to human error, not cyberattacks, and highlight the fragility of modern digital life dependent on cloud infrastructure.
keyTakeAways: The AWS outage was caused by a technical error during a software update to DynamoDB's API, which disrupted the Domain Name System (DNS), preventing apps from connecting to essential databases.

The failure cascaded across 113 AWS services, affecting major platforms including banking apps, gaming services (e.g., Roblox, Fortnite), communication tools (e.g., WhatsApp, Zoom), media companies (e.g., Netflix, The New York Times), and consumer devices (e.g., Alexa, Ring).
Cloud infrastructure is highly vulnerable to human error; AWS confirmed the root cause was not a cyberattack or external threat but a misstep in internal system updates.
Despite the widespread impact, AWS responded quickly, restoring full operations and acknowledging that the outage was contained and not a systemic failure.
This incident highlights the fragility of modern digital life, where even a single point of failure in a major cloud provider can cascade across the global internet ecosystem.
